citations.narrative:
The nonhuman primate food biscuits was stored in a storage shed within a plastic leakproof container that was not
elevated off the ground. Storing the food container on the floor of the storage shed may allow for any spillage of feed that
may occur to stay underneath the storage bin which may attract pests and/or vermin. The food supplies must be stored off
the floor and away from the walls, to allow for cleaning underneath and around the supplies.
Corrected at time of inspection.

The sheltered housing facilities (inside portion) for the non-human primates was above 85 degrees for more than 4 hours
while the summer outdoor temperatures reached the mid-90s. There is a fan in the indoor portion of the buildings for
ventilation, but currently no mechanism for cooling that can keep the temperature below the maximum allowed 85
degrees for no more than 4 hours. The indoor temperatures measured between 91.3 to 91.8 degrees at 2:30 pm (Kestrel)
within each shelter. At 2:30 pm that day, the outdoor temperature was already at 92 degrees and continued to rise to a
high of 94 degrees at 4:00 pm. The outdoor temperature did not fall below 85 degrees until 9:00 pm that evening per the
Accuweather website. Adequate temperature control is necessary to prevent heat stress of the nonhuman primates. The
ambient temperature in the sheltered part of the facility must not rise above 85 degrees for more than 4 consecutive hours
when non-human primates are present.
Corrected at time of inspection.

Sharp points were observed on the back right corner of the metal shelter for the pigs within their primary outdoor
enclosure where two metal panels that create the sides of the shelter met, leaving an approximately 3-inch gap with sharp
edges exposed for approximately 12 inches in height. These sharp edges could cause harm to the animals by allowing
injury from the exposed sharp points within their enclosure. The outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and
shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Corrected at time of inspection.
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by AUGUST 12, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
